Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Highly Conductive and Additive-free Aqueous MXene Inks for Smart Textile Applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of new inks for the electronic textile market. State-of-the-art conductive ink systems have complex chemistries. The proposed inks for smart textile applications address the environmental concerns, eliminate the pre- and post-treatment costs, and have better performance. This can be used for applications such as wearable sensors, antennas, and RFID tags.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of conductive and additive-free aqueous MXene inks that may be used as a dye to transform commercial yarns/fabrics into functional devices or as an ink for inkjet/screen printing devices directly on garments or soft surfaces. The proposed MXene ink formulation, which consists of only two-dimensional MXene sheets dispersed in water, may potentially solve the environmental and health concerns related to the use of other organic substances usually used as solvent in the preparation of conductive inks. Also, owing to seamless integration of MXene inks, the mechanical properties of the yarns and fabrics do not need to be modified after coating. Therefore, the resulting conductive yarns or devices are comfortable and safe to wear. Preliminary investigations have shown that the produced MXene-based yarns/fabrics may solve the manufacturability and washability problem of the conventional conductive yarns/fabrics while enabling seamless integration into textile-based devices. These issues have prevented translation of smart textiles despite their tremendous promise as a platform technology for functional devices.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcome Report

Award Title: I-Corps: Highly Conductive and Additive-free Aqueous MXene Inks for Smart Textile Applications

Federal Award ID: 2048759

MXene inks used for printing electronics or knitting/weaving of textile device provide a simple and cost-effective processability combined with high performance, which is required for widespread implementation of flexible on-chip and wearable devices. MXene ink formulations, which consists of only two-dimensional sheets of transition metal carbides dispersed in water, provide economical and processing benefits for ink chemists, manufacturers, and end users while offering environmental advantageous over other conventional competitor inks (i.e., silver inks) in the market. Working prototypes that have already been produced at the lab scale based on this platform technology include wearable sensors, textile supercapacitors, wireless antennas, and RFID tags.

The recent surge of interest in flexible and wearable electronics has resulted in new research efforts aimed at developing simple but effective conductive ink formulations that can functions in a wide array of technologies such as energy storage, sensing, actuation, and communication. However, many challenges related to manufacturability, integration, and the cost of printed electronics and smart textiles processed from conductive inks remains unaddressed. Our technology can result in additive-free aqueous MXene inks with tunable rheological properties to meet the basic requirements of various processing techniques widely used in printed electronic and smart textile industries. The absence of commonly added organic additives for ink formulation in the produced MXene inks eliminates their adverse effects on the mechanical and electronic properties of the final patterns or coated textiles/fibers.

This I-Corps project explored potential commercial application of highly conductive, additive-free aqueous MXene inks in the smart textile and printed electronic markets. MXene ink offers three orders of magnitude higher electrical conductivity than the carbon-based inks and a similar electrical conductivity to that of silver-based inks, but without the need for pre- and post-treatment. Also, other than their high electrical conductivity, MXenes are hydrophilic in nature, resulting in their excellent dispersibility in water (and other solvents) without the need for additional binders or surfactants. These properties provide a unique opportunity in manufacturing novel smart wearables as well as printed electronics and communication devices such as transparent electrodes, RFID tags, or wireless antennas. Customer discovery interviews and product-market studies carried out during this I-Corps project indicated that cost, scalability, and supply chain issues are among the key challenges that are currently hindering use of conductive MXene inks in wearable technologies, despite enormous interest from industry partners. In addition, our studies hint at a potential market fit and industrial interest for use of lightweight and flexible printed antennas produced from MXene inks in the automobile industry. Various certification steps, fund raising, attracting customers, and creating partnerships, quality control at the material and device levels, and research and development on ink formulations, however, remain the key aspects in the path toward obtaining a viable MXene antenna product in the long run.

The outcomes and findings of this I-Corps program shed light on key requirements and challenges for bringing MXene ink technology into the market of printed antennas and smart wearable technologies and can be used as a resource in determining the right value proposition for MXene enabled printed electronics and communication devices as well as development of a business model with cost structure and revenue stream information in related industries.

 


Last Modified: 08/12/2021
Modified by: Yury Gogotsi
